Award.AwardTitle: Cytoskeletal Regulation of Cell Wall Biosynthesis and Cell Morphogenesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit.
Plants build cells in a diverse range of shapes that are important both for specialized cell function and for creating the structure of the plant itself. To create these shapes, plant cells must organize the molecular structure and mechanical properties of the rigid walls that encase them. A highly ordered network of protein polymers known as the cortical microtubule cytoskeleton is employed to organize cell walls and to build specific cell shapes. The cortical microtubule cytoskeleton has been shown to (1) guide the trajectories of cellulose synthase complexes as they deposit cellulose, the major structural component of the cell wall; (2) position the delivery of these complexes to their sites of action at the cell membrane; and (3) tether trafficking organelles containing cellulose synthase in the cortex of the cell during conditions of stress. The molecular mechanisms by which the microtubule cytoskeleton carries out these activities are not known, and the precise biological functions of all these processes in cell growth and morphogenesis are not well understood. To investigate these questions the Ehrhardt lab designed a genetic screen for mutants that are defective in trafficking of cellulose synthase and its organization at the cell cortex and cell membrane. This screen revealed a class of mutants that are defective in CSC guidance and have lost cortical tethering, the lost mutants. These mutants are exciting tools to discover new molecules involved in cytoskeletal function, and to get new insight into the network of interactions that organize the cell wall. This project has three major experimental aims: (1) to investigate LOST function by characterizing these mutants at the levels of subcellular protein and organelle dynamics, cell and tissue growth, and cell wall structure; (2) to identify these genes and determine where the protein products reside in the cell and how they behave, and (3) to identify other proteins that interact with LOST proteins to build a molecular interaction and/or regulatory network from the microtubule cytoskeleton to the cell wall biosynthetic machinery. These studies will provide new insight into several central questions in plant cell biology: the function of the cortical cytoskeleton, the mechanisms of cell morphogenesis, and the mechanisms for biosynthesis and organization of cellulose and the cell wall - major targets of biofuel and biomaterials research.

Broader Impacts.
Integrating research and education. The research activities in this project will contribute to the training of a young post doctoral scientist and will give several high school students first hand exposure to basic research. These students will participate in the Carnegie Summer Internship Program, enhancing the student's experience through weekly research talks by Carnegie faculty and researchers and by giving them an opportunity to present their findings in a pubic forum. Materials from this research will be used in Stanford's Advanced Imaging Course. This course gives students hands on experience in building advanced instruments like laser traps and TIRF microscopes. Training of under represented groups in science. Summer research assistants will be recruited from local high schools with substantial minority representation. Other outreach activities include establishing collaborations with researchers in departments and institutions that only train undergraduates. Communication of research. Research results will be incorporated into the Ehrhardt lab website, deepgreen.stanford.edu. This site is used for class instruction at several universities around the world. Images and results from the lab have previously been incorporated into major textbooks.
Infrastructure development. The Ehrhardt lab has generated a database of fluorescent protein markers for plant cells and the associated molecular resources. Materials generated by this research will be added to this database and distributed by the lab's website and by the Arabidopsis stock center.
Other societal benefits. Cellulose provides the basis for mechanical support of terrestrial plant life and is the major sink for photosynthetic output. The molecular mechanisms that govern cellulose biosynthesis and cell wall organization have relevance for crop improvement, engineering of biomaterials, and biofuel development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The cortical microtubule cytoskeleton is required to organize the plant cell wall and to direct the patterns of cellular and organ growth.  At least functions of these cytoskeletal arrays have been identified: (1) guiding the trajectories of cellulose synthase complexes (CSCs) as they build the cell wall; (2) positioning the delivery of CSCs to the cell membrane, and (3) acting to tether compartments that carry CSCs under conditions of stress. The molecular mechanisms by which these activities are carried out are largely unknown, and the precise biological functions of these processes in cell growth and morphogenesis are not well understood. To investigate these questions, we designed a genetic screen for mutants that are defective in tethering of CSCs. This screen revealed a class of mutants that we call lost. The goal of this proposal is to exploit these mutants to gain new insight into several central questions in plant cell biology: the function of the cortical cytoskeleton, the mechanisms of cell morphogenesis, and the mechanisms for biosynthesis and organization of cellulose and the cell wall.

The two lost mutants identified in our microscopic screen were mapped by deep sequencing. Complementation tests of candidate genes and further sequencing analysis revealed that the lost mutations reside in a gene known as CSI1. The lost mutants were defective in both CSC guidance and in tethering of CSC compartments, indicating that a common linkage mechanism may be used for both functions.  Further phenotypic characterization revealed that LOST/CSI1 function is required to reorient the direction of new cellulose deposition in hypocotyl cells in response to light signaling and that lost mutants are defective in subsequent phototrophic growth. Lost mutants were also observed to have significant maternal and paternal fertility defects, indicating an important role of LOST/CSI1 in plant fecundity.

To build a molecular interaction and/or regulatory network from the microtubule cytoskeleton to the cell wall biosynthetic machinery, several screens have been performed and are in progress to identify LOST/CSI1 interacting proteins and proteins involved in LOST/CSI1 function.  These include a genetic suppressor screen following chemical mutagenesis and a screen for interacting membrane-associated proteins. A collection of candidates was identified from both these screens and further candidates are being sought using a technique known as proximity labeling to identify proteins that are nearby, but necessarily interacting with, LOST/CSI1.

The study of plant cell wall morphogenesis has been hindered by a lack of tools to manipulate and measure cell wall growth with high precision, and tools to visualize cell wall constituents in living cells with high specificity.  With support of this grant, we developed microfluidics systems and analytic tools to measure cell wall growth at high precision and to use rapid and reversible osmotic treatments to both manipulate cellular turgor and to measure cell wall mechanics. We have also partnered with Michael Hahn’s group to develop in vivo probes of cell wall polysaccharides using carbohydrate binding proteins and single chain anitibodies.  Two probes showing specific patterns of localization in the cell wall have been developed to date. 

Trophic growth in response to environmental cues is accompanied by reorganization of the cortical cytoskeleton which in turn directs new patterns of cellulose deposition.  We have revealed that severing of microtubules by katanin drives the creation of a new population of microtubules to rapidly reorient cortical microtubule arrays in response to blue light signaling. Using live cell imaging and computational modeling, we have found that the proteins SPR2 and CLASP act as important and specific stabilization factors for the new minus and plus ends created by severing, respectively.  These activities are required for normal array remodeling during the photrophic response.

Broader Impacts. This grant has supported the training of two post docs who are planning careers as independent researchers, and has given experience in performing and presenting basic research to an undergraduate from a local community college.  Activities supported by this grant have aided the career development of a junior faculty member at Santa Clara University, an institution that only educates undergraduates in the life sciences. Results these studies were incorporated into the Advanced Imaging course at Stanford University and findings were published in five peer reviewed publications.  Insights into the molecular mechanisms of cytoskeletal direction of cell wall biosynthesis are relevant for our broader understanding of morphogenesis across organisms that produce walls, including bacteria and fungi, and our studies of microtubule array reorganization by severing have shown the first direct evidence in any system that this conserved activity can act to build new microtubule arrays.
